loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 50 years old and is engaged in a hog fattening business as a source of income. She is blessed with four children to send to school and provides for their needs. Erlinda and her husband are helping each other to earn a higher income to achieve their desired standard of living. Her husband works as a farmer while she works on her hog fattening business.

She wants to provide better sustenance to her hogs, therefore she has requested a loan amount of PHP 5,000 to buy feeds and vitamins. Given that nutrition and sustenance, she can sell her hogs at a higher price. She hopes to gain higher sales in order to provide for the needs of her children.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en:
Florentina is 53 years old and has been engaged in the piggery business for seven years. She said it is not easy work to take on this occupation. But because of the determination and inspiration that her children provide, she does everything for the benefit of their underprivileged lifestyle.

For that reason, Florentina is asking for a loan amount PHP 5,000 to provide for the needs of her pigs by giving them better feeds and vitamins. She is dreaming to become one of the fortunate dealers of pigs among different municipalities in their province. She is patiently growing her business into a bigger venture. She hopes that someday she will achieve her dream and lift her family from poverty.

loans.use: to provide for the needs of her pigs with such things as feeds and vitamins

loans.name: Elmie

texts.en:
Elmie is a former Overseas Filipino Worker in Bahrain. She earned enough income for her family, but because of the hard work she was forced to return home. On her return, she engaged herself in the hog fattening business.

She is 48 years old and blessed with four children. Through her business, she is sending her children to school. Within three years of operating her business, she is earning an average amount of PHP 1,500 every month, but this is not enough to provide their needs.

Thus, Elmie is requesting a loan amount PHP 4,000 to buy two more hogs as an additional source of profit. She hopes to earn higher than expected income for the improvement of their living conditions as well as to save for the educational purposes of her children.

loans.use: to buy two more hogs as additional source of profit

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda spends most of her time in raising pigs. She had been married for almost eight years but not yet been blessed with a child. The couple are praying to have a child too. Through hog raising, Rosalinda was able to earn a profit of PHP 1,000 for each hog she was able to sell to the butchers who came to their village. She used it to pay monthly electric bills and for daily meals. The other part of the income was used as revolving capital for the maintenance of her hogs.

She is now asking for a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy a new piglet to raise and to use for their maintainance in hog feed, medicines and vitamins. Through the help of this loan she will be able to strengthen her business and acquire more profit from it.

In the future, Rosalinda would like to achieve financial stability.

loans.use: to buy a new piglet to raise and to use for their maintainance in hog feed, medicines and vitamins.

loans.name: Tetyana

texts.en:
Tetyana is divorced with two grown children. She is an entrepreneur from Beregovo, Western Ukraine, and she sells retail household items in a busy place in the local market that attracts many potential customers. Tetyana has been in this trade for nine years and presently has 40,000 Grivnyas invested in her inventory. Her monthly net profit amounts to 6,000 Grivnyas.

Tetyana is requesting a loan of 15,000 Grivnyas to purchase dishes, plates, cutlery, pans, cups, and other items. Operating her business with integrity and skill, she is looked up to by others as an entrepreneur of authority and intelligence. Additional merchandise, combined with Tetyana’s work ethic and experience, will enable her to expand her business, increase her income, and continue growing as an entrepreneur.

loans.use: to purchase dishes, plates, cutlery, pans, cups, and other items.

loans.name: Felix

texts.en:
Felix is 50 years old and has been in the business of buying and selling of corn and rice for 20 years. It has served as his way to uplift their poor living conditions. Despite of his age, he pursues his business to achieve success in terms of money. 

He states, "Money by this generation is very powerful. You can buy all earthly things if you have a lot of money. But I am scraping a lot of effort just to earn a better profit. Hopefully, our Creator will help me in achieving my dream so I can also extend my help to the needy person as Alalay sa Kaunlaran Inc. doing”. 

With the loan amount of PHP 5,000 this will be a big factor to improve more of his business. He will be going to buy a new weighing scale as an instrument used for purchasing and selling his products.

loans.use: to buy a new weighing scale as an instrument used for purchasing and selling his products.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is 46 years old and married to Jesus. They were blessed with two kids. She considers a piggery business as a precious source of income because it provides their needs, especially the educational needs of her kids. She wants to expand her business and become one of the hog dealers in their community. 

Because of her willingness to survive and change their poor lifestyle, she never surrenders. She faces and fights poverty. She is asking for a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy three more pigs and feed. She hopes it will provide a better profit in order to afford all their every day needs without experiencing scarcity.

loans.use: to buy three more pigs and feed

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
This is Vilma, 32, a resident of Baseco, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Felicito, a porter, and she is a mother to their three children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their every day expenses.

Vilma operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns an income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Vilma hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams of giving her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to sell

loans.name: Gerberta

texts.en:
Gerberta is 50 years old and the mother of nine children.  Her children are already married. That’s why she and her husband are working for themselves. She wants to earn even while staying at home, as her husband goes in the field. So she decided to sell loads (phone cards) as a source of income. As of now, she is earning PHP 300 daily, which she uses to buy their every day needs, such as food.

She wants to increase her net profit to improve their living conditions, so Gerberta is asking for a loan of PHP 3,000 to buy additional loads to sell. She hopes she can change their every day lifestyle into a better one by earning a daily income.

loans.use: to buy additional loads (phone cards) to sell

loans.name: Anna

texts.ru:
Анна замужем. У них с ее мужем Андреем трое детей. Живут в двух комнатной квартире в городе Ивано-Франковске. Вместе с мужем Анна ведет семейный бизнес.

Анна торгует на центральном продуктовом рынке. Ее торговая  точка находится на въезде в рынок. Анна торгует овощами и фруктами.  У нее большой ассортимент и низкие цены.  Анна целеустремленная и трудолюбивая. Этот бизнес является  главным доходом семьи. Цель Анны дать детям высшее образование.

Анна просит предоставить ей кредит в сумме 10,000 гривен на закупку на закупку фруктов к сезону консервации и цитрусовых. Получив доход, она сможет переоформить автомобиль, который они недавно приобрели для бизнеса.
texts.en: Anna is married.  She and her husband Andrey have three children.  They live in a two-room apartment in the town of Ivano-Frankivsk.  Anna and her husband have their own business.  Anna sells vegetables and fruits at the central produce market.  Her retail outlet is located at the market entrance.  She has a wide selection of products and low prices.  Anna is a goal-oriented and hard-working person.  This business is the main source of income for her family.  Anna's goal is to provide her children with a higher education.  Anna is requesting a loan in the sum of 10,000 hryvnia for the purchase of fruits for the pickling season.  Having received an income, she would be able to refinance a vehicle that they purchased for the business.

loans.use: to buy fruits for the pickling season

loans.name: Mary Vic

texts.en:
Mary Vic is a mother who has great ambitions for her family. She is 31 years old and has three school-age children. She wants them to earn degrees and become professionals someday. Despite the hardships of life, she and her husband are striving hard to earn income and support the education of their children. 
 
They have owned and managed a rice farming business in their village for almost eight years. Usually they earn a profit of only P28,000 from every harvest season. They aim to increase their yields and income so they can meet their needs and finance the education of their children.

Due to inadequate capital, Mary Vic is asking for a loan of P50,000 to buy fertilizers, pesticides, and seeds, and to pay the labor cost incurred in planting rice. She believes that this loan will help her and her husband to increase their yields and income as they work hard and manage it well. She hopes that she will achieve her goals and become successful in the future.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, pesticides, and seeds, and and to pay the labor cost incurred in planting rice.

loans.name: Myrnalyn

texts.en:
Myrnalyn is 31 years old, an industrious mother who works in a hog-fattening business. She was blessed with three children to educate, so she works hard to earn a higher profit. She has been doing this work for two years and earns P3,000 every selling season.


She is requesting a loan of P5,000 to buy feed and vitamins for her hogs. She hopes to make the hogs healthy to boost her net income at selling time. This will help to improve her family's living condition.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her hogs.

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
This is Leonila, 41, a resident of Baseco, Manila, Philippines. She is a single parent with two children. Together with her children, she manages their household while operating the business. She works hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Leonila operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns profit by buying supplies in bulk at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Leonila hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams to be able to give her children a good, high-quality education through her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. At these meetings, she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en:
Dominga is 39 years old.  She buys and sells rice and corn as her main source of income. She has been doing this for four years and earns P200 every day. This is not enough for her family but she budgets carefully in order to be self-sufficient. 


She is requesting a loan of P5,000 to buy more rice to sell. She hopes to earn a higher income through the help of this loan. She works hard to meet the needs of her family including her children's education. She hopes her children will earn degrees and improve their living condition.

loans.use: to buy additional rice to sell.

loans.name: Glenda

texts.en:
Glenda raises and sells pigs as her primary source of income. 

At the age of 26, she needs to work hard to meet the needs of her two children and family. She dreams of lifting her family from poverty, so she works patiently as an owner of a piggery business. She is requesting a loan of P5,000 to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. 

She hopes this will make them provide higher prices when they are sold.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Mely

texts.en:
Mely is 56 years old and she has been widowed for almost 10 years. She has to generate income and provide sustenance for her two children. But due to he expensive cost of studies, her eldest child had to stop from going to college and Mely felt guilty about it. 

Mely has been selling fruits and vegetables, particularly bananas, to the people in the village for almost 20 years. She offers it house to house. She usually earns P200 a day, but it is not enough to cover her family's daily consumption. 

She is requesting a loan of P5,000 to buy bananas, eggplants and tomatoes to sell in the village and increase her earnings. In the future, Mely would like to improve her sales and save for the college education of her children so they have a degree and good employment someday.

loans.use: to buy bananas, eggplants and tomatoes to sell in the village

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina is a farmer’s wife who engages in the selling of fruits and vegetables in their community. Because of their poor living condition she needs to work hard. She doesn’t want to depend on her husband. With further improvement to their living condition, she also helps in uplifting their lifestyle.

Rosalina is 47 years old and does not have any children at all. Since she was not blessed, she helps her nephew in school. She still pursues a life in helping others. Consequently, she is asking a loan amount P5,000 to buy cabbages, beans, squash and cucumbers as additional goods to sell.

She hopes this will lead to a boom in her income and her business to prosper. Thus she can enrich her help to her needy relative, now that she has no children.

loans.use: to buy cabbages, beans, squash and cucumbers as additional goods to sell.

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
Estelita, 48, lives with her husband and three children at the village of Sto. Domingo Alfonso lista, Ifugao.

Estelita has been raising and selling pigs for almost 10 years. She gives them feed and, once they arrive at an optimum size and weight, she offers them to her customers or to different villages near-by. With the income she obtains she is able to meet their household expenses.

She requests a loan of amount of P5,000 to buy stock feed so that she can minimize her fare expenses in going to and from the market. According to her, she requested additional capital because if her pigs are well-fed then she can offer them to her buyers at a better price. So, Estelita works hard in order to save money and give her family a quality life.

loans.use: to buy feed for her raised pigs

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Carolina is 45 years old and engaged in buying and selling of bananas. She was blessed with four children, and to provide for their needs, especially educational needs, requires finance. Hence Carolina is working hard to earn enough money to sustain their needs.

She dreams to expand and maximize her business through asking for a loan amount of P5,000 to buy additional bananas, avocados and pineapples to sell. This could increase her net sales and allow her to be able to save for the future of her beloved children. She hopes to finish their education in order for them to acquire a better living and not to suffer forever from poverty.

loans.use: to buy additional bananas, avocados and pineapples to sell

loans.name: Jaime

texts.en:
Jaime is 51, married, and has two adult children. He is a hard working father who owns and manages a rice farm business in their village, and usually earns a profit of only P23,000 in every harvest season. He aims to increase his yields and income for he wants to save for future emergencies, and put up a grocery store in the future for his wife to manage. 

Due to financial difficulty, he is asking for an additional capital of P20,000 to buy seeds, fertilizers, pesticides and other expenses incurred in planting rice. He mentioned that through this loan, he will be able to expand his plantation and manage it well. He hopes that through patience and hard work, he will increase his yields and make his business grow.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, pesticides and other expenses incurred in planting rice

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida is 41 years old. She buys and sells vegetables to earn an income. She has been doing this for five years and earns an average of 7,000 PHP every month. This was not sufficient to pay for the education of her five children; as a result, her husband is also working more just to provide for all of their family's needs. As her four children go to school, Nida's youngest goes with her to sell vegetables because she has no one else to look after him.

Nida wishes to increase her monthly income, which is why she is asking for a loan of 7,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy additional goods to sell such as squash, beans, onions, ginger, and garlic. This could provide increased income that she would use to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy squash, beans, onions, ginger, and garlic

loans.name: Jovita

texts.en:
Jovita is two years now operating her hog fattening business but is still struggling to reach her desired income. She wants to earn more than her usual profit to have support for the education of her two children. Right now she is prioritizing her hog fattening business in order to make her business progress.


For this reason, she is requesting a loan amount of 5000 PHP to buy one hog to raise and hog food and vitamins. She hopes this will provide a better income for the betterment of their current living as well as for the educational purposes of her children.

loans.use: to buy one hog to raise and hog feed and vitamins.

loans.name: Sanabarhan's Group

texts.en:
Sanabarhan is the leader of this group. She is 36 and married to a construction worker whose monthly salary is 5000 soms. Together with her husband she brings up two daughters and two sons. The sons and the older daughter are at school and the second daughter is preschool age (under seven). Seven years ago, with an initial investment of 6000 soms, Sanabarhan started to sell dishes at the market. In this way she earns about 5000 soms per month. With the profits gained from the trade she purchased livestock for breeding. At the moment she keeps a cow and a calf.  With money received from the loan Sanabarhan wants to purchase two livestock animals for breeding, fattening and further reselling. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Letcia is 52 years old and married to a farmer named Rolando. They are helping each other in earning income to provide a better living. She has no children but  she is helping her siblings in sending their children to school.


Because of this, she is asking for a loan of 5000 PHP to buy feed and vitamins for her hogs. She wants to expand her business and overcome her poor living situation to help more people especially her nephews. She hopes this loan will be a big factor in helping her to achieve her desired living condition.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her hogs.

loans.name: Revelina

texts.en:
Reveline is 53 years old and the mother of three children.  Her two children are already married. That’s why she and her husband are working for the education of their youngest child. She wants to finish her youngest child's education to have an accomplishment for her children. She said that she is very happy when she sends her child through her education. She could consider herself a winner though two of her children married early.

To provide the needs of her school-aged child, she engaged herself in operating a hog fattening business. She already has five years of experience in this occupation and is earning a net income of PHP 2,000 every time she sells her hogs. She wants to increase her usual income, so she is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy two more hogs as an additional source of net income and feed for her hogs. She wants to save for their future, especially for school for her child.

loans.use: to buy two more hogs and feed

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is a devoted mother who has dedicated herself to her livestock. She has been characterized as a very spirited and strong person whose successes are directly applied to her family, which is composed of her husband and children. Teresita raises livestock for sale. It is necessary to point out that this is the only income that supports her family and her family really needs it. 

Teresita is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 for additional income for her livestock business to buy feed, vitamins and other needs.

With this loan, her beloved family will benefit as much as she will.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her chickens and pigs

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
Belinda, who is 39 years old, lives with her husband and children. With this loan, she intends to buy concentrated feed to fatten up her pigs. She owns a herd of pigs and plans to feed them concentrated feed so that they fatten up faster. She wants her animals to reach the ideal weight for their subsequent sale in the local market or in neighboring communities. 

Belinda wants to generate the maximum profit for her well-being and that of her family and to help expand her pig-raising project.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Marciana

texts.en:
Marciana, 47, is married and lives with her husband and three children. She intends to use the loan to buy concentrate to fatten up her pigs. She has several pigs and she intends to feed them concentrate to fatten them up more quickly. She wants her animals to be at a better weight to the sell them at her local market or in surrounding areas. She wants to earn the most profit possible for her and her family’s well being, and to grow the pig raising project. 

She is asking for a loan of PHP 5,000 (Philippine pesos) to buy feeds and vitamins so that her pigs are a better weight when she sells them.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Efelia

texts.en: Efelia sells fruit in their village. She has done this for many years now, providing fruit and vegetables to all of her customers. She buys the fruit and vegetables early in the morning, and sometimes she brings it to the market. She is requesting this loan to buy the fruit and vegetables. She is a young, enterprising woman who helps her family economically through her work. She helps provide food for her husband and children and hopes to help them until they are professionals. This is one of her most important goals, as circumstances in life have meant that she has had to take care of her family. She is always thinking about her family's well-being and has a desire to get ahead and improve the quality of life of her loved ones.

loans.use: to buy beans, cabbage and squash for her store

loans.name: Adoracion

texts.en:
Adoracion is 50 years old, married, and has three adult children. She has been managing her hog raising business for almost 20 years, and her income supports the family. Since her parents struggled financially, she wasn’t able to finish her studies, and was also married early.  Adoracion doesn't want her children to experience the same hardship as she has. She is determined to send them both to school. Profits earned form the business are being saved in preparation for her children's education. 

Adoracion is now asking for a loan of PHP 11,000 to buy hog feed and vitamins to ensure good nutrition for the pigs. With good nutrition, she will be able to sell the hogs at a higher price when they are ready for sale.  In the future, Adoracion wants to achieve financial stability. She also wants to see both of her children get a degree and good employment.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda is 27 years old and lives with her husband and children in her own house, which has water and electricity. It is located in the province of Isabela. This region is characterized by its agriculture, cattle-raising, and tourist activities. For some years Rosalinda has sold basic groceries (cabbage, tomato and some fruit, etc.) from her home. She tries to cover all family expenses and necessities with her earnings.

Rosalinda is a responsible and hard-working person who is concerned that her family get ahead, and she wants to offer her children better educational options in the future.

loans.use: to buy cabbage, tomatoes, and leafy vegetables for sale

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet is 34 years old, married, and has three children who are in school.  She is a very hard working entrepreneur who has a frozen foods business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for two years. She has requested a PHP 14,000 loan to buy more food to sell in her food stall.  She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy frozen foods like hotdogs and sweet meats to sell

loans.name: Elenita

texts.en:
Elenita is 29 years old, married and has two children who are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 
Elenita has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She has requested a loan of 13,000 PHP through Kiva partner, NWTF, to buy more fish to sell from her food stall.
Elenita has been in this business for eight years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to be able to afford to send her children to college and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Bedan

texts.en: Bedan is 26 years old and married.  To earn a living, he sells second-hand goods such as furniture.  He started his business five years ago.  Through Faulu Kenya, he has learned how to save his money and manage his business because he has been trained in business management skills.  He hopes to expand his business and employ people.  He has requested 50, 000 Kenyan shillings to buy seats, beds and wall units.

loans.use: To  buy seats, beds and wall units.

loans.name: Villamor

texts.en:
Villamor believes that "Success is the fruit of patience and sacrifices". He is an industrious farmer who raised his family in a village, planting and harvesting rice for sale. He is now 56 years old and has only one child. Together with his wife, he has been managing their 1.5 hectares of farm land for almost 33 years now, and usually earns a net profit of PHP 25,000 every harvest season. 

Due to the high cost of commodities and transportation, Villamor is asking for a loan of PHP 50,000 to buy seeds, fertilizers, pesticides and other necessaries associated with planting rice.  He believes that through patience and hard work, he will increase their yields and income. He is hoping that in the future, they will earn and save more for future emergencies and renovate their own house so they can live more comfortably.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, pesticides and necessaries associated with planting rice.

loans.name: Guerlita

texts.en:
Guerlita is 60 years old and married with two children. She works hard to provide for her family by running a sari-sari store in the Philippines. She has requested a loan of 15,000 PHP through Kiva partner, NWTF, to buy more items to sell in her store.
Guerlita has borrowed and paid back 15 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 18 years and also earns an income from trisikad transport and raising carabao.
Guerlita aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell in her store.

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah works hard to support her family. Leah is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

Leah requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy a new engine for her fishing boat and other equipment.

Leah has been in this business for 6 years now and also earns additional income from raising livestock.

In the future Leah would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy a new engine for her fishing boat and other equipment.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is 40-years-old and married with 4 children.

Myrna works hard to provide for her family. She runs a variety store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 28000 loan through NWTF to buy stocks of merchandise for her store.

Myrna has borrowed and paid 16 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the variety store for 3 years and also earns an income from raising pigs.

Myrna aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy stocks of merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Glory

texts.en:
Glory lives in the village of Sto. Domingo Alfonso Lista, a mountainous area in which there is a lot of corn farming. She is happily living with her husband and four children. Glory describes herself as an industrious and patient mother. 

Glory has been raising hogs for almost 10 years. According to her, the business has served as an income source for their daily needs and for the education of her children. Now, Glory is glad because her four children have finished their education.

Glory is looking for a loan of P5,000 to buy feed for her hog raising business. Since her children finished their education, Glory has wanted to develop her business, earn a higher income and save some money for financial security when she cannot work.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma is 57-years-old and married with 2 children. Thelma works very hard to provide for them.

Thelma runs a Sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell.

Thelma has been in this business for 7 years and sells a variety of items such as soap, noodles, sugar, and other groceries. 

In the future Thelma would like to save money to expand her business and to repair her family home.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 19,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food vending business.

Wilma has been in this business for 10 years. Wilma earns additional income from a general store.

Wilma has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she can continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food business.

loans.name: Emily

texts.en: Emily is a business woman aged 30. She is married and blessed with one child. For the past two years, she has been managing a salon to earn a living. Her desire is to open a boutique in five years time so that she can get more income. She is requesting a loan of 15,000 Kenya shillings to buy a hair drier and make-up. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, she has been able to save part of her income.

loans.use: To buy a hair drier and make-up

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita is a goal-oriented and diligent person. She is the mother of two. Instead of lazing at home, she works in a retail business as source of income. She sells both food and daily-use products such as soap, shampoo, instant noodles, bread and eggs. She operates the business in front of her house. She usually earns about P5,000 monthly. She uses this to pay for monthly electricity bills, daily meals and allowances for her children. 

She is asking for a loan of P26,000 to buy soft drinks, canned goods, sugar, cooking oil and vinegar to increase grocery stock in her store. It will also help attract more customers. 

In the future, Clarita would like to establish a more convenient store. She hopes to save enough money for the college education of her children. She wants them to have good employment some day.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, canned goods, sugar, cooking oil and vinegar to sell

loans.name: Elinor

texts.en:
Elinor, a divorced mother of two grown children, lives in Bnei Brak. For the past several years, she has given group and private exercise training lessons and massage therapy. In the past, Elinor ran her group lessons and private sessions in different studios and gyms. After careful calculation and business consultation, Elinor decided to open a studio in her home. With her eldest child already reaching adulthood and making a home of her own, Elinor had the extra space and converted an area into a studio. This allows her to save transportation and rental costs and precious time she had to allocate to reach the other locations. While a small number of clients will continue to have lessons at an outside studio, the majority of her business is relocating to her home-based studio.

Elinor needed this loan to purchase weights, exercise mats, pilates balls, and lighting fixtures and to create PR flyers.

While a good number of Elinor's clients have moved to her home-based studio, she does still hold classes at outside studios. In the future, she hopes to work almost exclusively out of her studio, providing classes throughout the week.

loans.use: To purchase weights, exercise mats, and pilates balls and create PR flyers.

loans.name: Mirbat

texts.en:
Mirbat is from the village of Majed Al'krum in northern Israel. For 11 years, she worked at a hair salon and studied to be a stylist. For the last seven years, she has run a small hair salon out of her home. In addition, she began supplementing her income by selling nightgowns and pajamas for women. After developing a small but loyal clientele, Mirbat decided it was time to establish a hair salon outside of the home. She found an excellent, central location that is convenient for her current customers and will draw new ones easily. Mirbat is opening her salon with a section dedicated to selling nightgowns and women's undergarments.

She needed this loan to purchase stock, cosmetic supplies, lotions creams and hair products.

In the future, Mirbat wants to further expand the retail side of her salon and see its expansion. Most importantly, she is striving to become economically independent.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetic supplies, lotions, creams and hair products.

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en: Thomas is a hardworking businessman aged 44. He is married and blessed with four children who are still in school. For the past two years, he has been managing a retail shop to earn a living. In the next 5 years he wants to expand his business. His dream is to manage a wholesale business. He is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy sugar and maize flour.

loans.use: To buy sugar and maize flour

loans.name: Adina

texts.en:
Adina is a 47-year-old mother of three. She lives in the northern community of Har Halutz. For several years, after training and certification, Adina worked in reflexology on the side. She works during the day as the school secretary and in the afternoons and evenings had been giving reflexology sessions. She has created a strong network of contacts, providing private therapy, and holding seminars at community centers and schools on reflexology. Many from her community and those surrounding ones turn to her for her services. Adina's clients include regular ones from the area and tourists staying at the B&Bs during the year. As her client base and the demands for her therapy have grown, Adina needs a studio for her ever-growing business activity. She is transforming an area of her home into a private, separate studio for clients. 

Adina has invested her own funds and needs this loan to assist with costs for the furnishings and supplies and for the costs of developing her website and PR.

Adina hopes in the future to earn the majority of her income through her business and not be dependent on other work.

loans.use: To pay for furnishings, supplies, a website and PR.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario is 55 years old, married to Julio, and lives in Ilagan, Isabela. They are blessed with three children: Julie – 28 years old, a college graduate who works as a call center agent, Julio – 24 years old, a college graduate who works as a nurse, and Janica – 16 years old who is in junior high school. 

Rosario says her canteen is situated in an urban area where there are many customers, especially during school days because many high school and college students come to her store. She is requesting a loan to purchase more and varied food items to sell in the canteen. This will increase her customers' purchases and the number of customers who come to her business.

“I dream to become a successful businesswoman someday so that I will be able to give my children a good future. That is why I really try hard," Rosario says. She hopes to open a grocery store next to her canteen.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snack foods, and drinks for her store

loans.name: Abbass

texts.en:
Abbass is a 25-year-old married man from Lebanon who lives with his wife and two children. Two years ago, he opened a small shop where he started selling mobile phones, cosmetics, and perfumes. The young man's newly-started business needs so much support to move forward. So today, he is requesting to borrow $3000 from Kiva partner Al Majmoua to increase his store’s inventory of recharge cards and to add necessary decoration to keep his shop attractive to new customers. This is Abbass' fourth cycle as Al Majmoua borrower. His previous loans reflected positively on his business growth and on his family's social and financial situations. He notes that the loan will help him fulfill his objectives and will positively impact his business growth and development the same way as the previous ones did.
His shop is located next to a hospital, which provides him with an increase in the number of customers, and is not dependent on the villagers and neighbors. He hopes to keep on expanding his business to provide his family with the good standard of living they deserve to have.

loans.use: To increase his store inventory by adding a new mobile phone and accessories collection, and to add necessary decoration

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase new home furniture

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Asymas

texts.en:
Asymas (in the photo) assists in her husband’s fishing business. Her husband is a fisherman. They live in a village along National Road number 6, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have six children, three sons and three daughters. Four are in school and other two are still young. 

Asymas is asking for another loan of $500 to buy additional fishing nets for her husband.

loans.use: To buy additional fishing nets for her husband.

loans.name: Hermosilia

texts.en:
Hermosilia is 51-years-old and married with 4 children.

Hermosilia is in the agricultural business raising cattle in the Philippines. Hermosilia requested a PHP 29,500 loan through NWTF to buy nutritionally-balanced feed for her cows.

Hermosilia has been raising cattle for 10 years now and has borrowed 24 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

Hermosilia would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy nutritionally-balanced feed for her cows.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Peterson

texts.en:
Peterson is a businessman who does tailoring.  He has been in the business for six years and has employed two people.  He also does farming to earn extra income for his family.  Through Faulu Kenya, he was able to buy business premises where he now operates his business.  So far, he has employed two people in his business. His desire is to expand his business in five years for more income.
Peterson has requested a loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings to buy fabric.

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en: Felisa is a businesswoman who has a small grocery store where she sells basic daily needs such as canned goods, shampoo, spices, body creams and other products. She has benefited from prior loans, which she invested in her business. The current loan that she is requesting is to purchase basic grains such as rice, sugar, canned goods, snack foods, and candies to sell. In addition, she will buy cosmetics such as lotions, creams and shampoo. Her husband and children help her tend to the business after they arrive home from school.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, canned good, snack foods, and candies for her store

loans.name: Chanry

texts.en:
Chanry (in the photo) and her husband, Nget, live in a village outside of Phnom Penh City. They have two young children: one son and one daughter. 

Chanry is a garment worker, while her husband is a construction. She is asking for a loan of $700 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Azucena

texts.en:
Azucena is 51 years old and married with three children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.
Azucena sells ready-to-wear clothing in the Philippines. She has requested a loan of 19,500 PHP through Kiva partner, NWTF, to buy pants, blouses, slippers etc. to sell on her stall.
Azucena has been in this business for 20 years. In the future, she would like to save enough to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy pants, blouses, slippers etc. for resale.

loans.name: Rona

texts.en:
Rona is 46 years old and married with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. Rona runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has requested a loan of 25,000 PHP through Kiva partner, NWTF, to purchase more stock to sell.
Rona has borrowed and paid back 12 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 12 years and also earns an income from food vending.
Rona aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sophy

texts.en:
Sophy (pictured here) is a weaver and raises pigs at home. Her husband, Heng, is a farmer. He does fishing and construction work when he is free from farming. The couple has four sons and four daughters. They live on an island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sophy is asking for a loan of $700 to assist in her husband’s farming business by buying a water pumping machine and pig feed.

loans.use: To buy a water pumping machine and pig feed.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines. She works hard to support her family. Susan has requested a loan of 20,000 PHP through Kiva partner, NWTF, to buy fishing gear and other equipment. She has been in this business for 15 years.
In the future, Susan would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Eralyn

texts.en:
Eralyn is 33 years old and married with two children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.
Eralyn has a sari-sari store business in the Philippines. She has requested a loan of 10,000 PHP through Kiva partner, NWTF, to purchase more goods such as soap, soft drinks etc. for resale.
Eralyn has been in this business for five years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to be able to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more goods such as soap, soft drinks, etc. for resale.

loans.name: Sokneang

texts.en:
Sokneang is a weaver. In addition, she also buys some finished products from other weavers in her village and transports them to sell in other provinces away from her house. Her husband is a security guard. She is asking for a loan of $400 to buy weaving materials for her weaving business and to buy finished products to sell.  

The couple has been married for almost 15 years and has three sons. Two are attending school and one stays at home. They live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Photo: Sokneang with her loom.

loans.use: To buy weaving materials and finished products to sell

loans.name: Tong

texts.en:
Tong (pictured with her loom) and her husband, Phat, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have three sons and three daughters. Three are married and live in separate homes, one is a construction worker, one has full-time employment and one is a weaver. 

Tong is a weaver, while her husband is a farmer and raises cows at home. She hopes to continue her weaving business because it’s a traditional profession. That’s why Tong is asking for another loan of $400 USD to buy weaving materials.

loans.use: To buy weaving materials

loans.name: Moussa

texts.en:
Moussa is a 53-year-old, married man and the father of six children.

Moussa has been an owner of a food market since 2008. He sells soft drinks, juices and cheese and dairy products. He has 20 years experience in this field. He has a deep understanding of local consumer needs. His market is situated in a crowded area so there are a good number of customers passing by as well as nearby school students and teachers.

Moussa decided to apply for a $2000 loan to buy new, good value products for his market. This loan is requested from Al Majmoua- Kiva partner and this is his fifth cycle as an Al Majmoua borrower of very good standing.

Moussa is aiming to earn more profit to provide a better life for his family.

loans.use: To buy new products to sell

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en: Nenita, a 58-year-old married mother of one, is a very hardworking entrepreneur who has been buying and selling coconut wine in the Philippines for 10 years. Now requesting a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase more gallons of coconut wine to sell, Nenita would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more gallons of coconut wine to sell.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en:
Sandra is 33 years old, married and has five children, three of whom are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 
Sandra has a sari-sari store business in the Philippines. She has requested a loan of 15,000 PHP through Kiva partner, NWTF, to buy items such as shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her sari-sari store.
Sandra has been in this business for a year. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items such as shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries for his grocery store.

loans.name: Paz

texts.en: Paz is 56 years old and a widow with three children. Paz works very hard to provide for them. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a 15,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell in her store. Paz has been in this business for 15 years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, detergent and other groceries. Paz would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell in her store

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
This is Nelson, 46, a resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. He is single and manages his household while operating his business. He works hard to continually generate income for his everyday expenses.  

Nelson operates a piggery. He sells live hogs to meat dealers. Sometimes he has the pigs slaughtered and sold at the market. He also operates a farm from which he gets additional income. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of Php 5000 in sales every week.

To help him continue business operations, he is requesting a Php40, 000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy feed and additional hogs. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands.  

Nelson hopes that his business will continue to be successful. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional feed & piglets

loans.name: Gulaiym's Group

texts.en:
Gulaiym is the leader of this group. She is 49 and is married to a driver whose monthly salary is 5000 soms. Together with her husband she brings up four sons, all of whom are working in Russia. Each month they transfer some money to Gulaiym to meet daily needs. To earn additional money Gulaiym breeds livestock and sells dairy products. She buys milk in the village and then resells it in the city. In this way she earns 4000 soms per month. With the loan she wants to purchase two sheep for breeding. In the future Gulaiym plans to open a poultry farm.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is married and has a fish vending business in the Philippines.  She works hard to support her family. 

Lydia has requested a 10,000 Philippine peso loan through Kiva field partner NWTF to buy more fish to sell in her food stall.  She has been in this business for 14 years.  In the future, Lydia hopes to be able to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Asteria

texts.en:
According to Asteria, " Hard work is the only way to overcome poverty". This is her inspiring principle in life. She is a mother who is now 47 years old and has four school-aged children. They have owned and managed a rice farm in their village for almost 27 years now. They endure hardships and difficulties in life for they want to educate their children and give them a better life.

They want to ask for additional capital of P20,000 to buy seeds, fertilizers, insecticides and to pay for other expenses in planting rice. She mentioned that they need to work hard and strive harder to increase their yields this coming harvest season. She is hoping that, some day, all of their children will earn a degree and that their standard of living will improve.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, insecticides and pay for other rice planting expenses

loans.name: Norma

texts.en: Norma is 52 years old and married with three children. With one child in school, Norma works very hard to provide for them. Norma buys and sells coconut shells in the Philippines. She requested a 30,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell. Norma has been in this business for five years. In the future, Norma would like to save enough to build a house for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Bibiana

texts.en: Bibiana is 59 years old and married with five children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines. She has been running the sari-sari store for eight years and also earns income from buying and selling livestock. Bibiana has requested a 20,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc., in her sari-sari store. Bibiana has borrowed and repaid five loans from NWTF before this loan. Bibiana aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in her sari-sari store

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose has been rearing chickens for sale in Kiambu town for the past nine years. She is 40 years old and is married to Patrick. They have three children.

She was introduced to KADET by a KADET client. She has repaid other loans well and in good time. She intends to use the loan to buy chicks to raise and later sell at a profit.

In the future Rose hopes to expand her business and open a shop.

loans.use: to buy chicks to raise and sell

loans.name: Utulivu Group

texts.en:
Bakari, who is in his early 30's, is married with one small child.  He has been selling mosquito nets for three years now.  He works from 8 a.m to 7 p.m daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be his 3rd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He used the previous loans to start building his small house, bought window frames, door frames and increased on the mosquito net stock. He has paid back all his loans successfully. He wants a loan to buy more mosquito nets to sell and iron sheets for the house he is building. His dream is to one day be able to open a hardware shop.

He will share this loan with his loan group "Utulivu" which has a total of 15 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more mosquito nets to sell and iron sheets for the house he is building.

loans.name: Zahida's Group

texts.en:
Zahida is a 39-year-old woman, professionally a seamstress. She has also started a business selling clothes to earn better profits. She purchases clothes from the wholesale markets and sells on good profits. She started this business on her customers’ demand.  Her variety of clothes enables her to receive good orders from her customers every month. 
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her clothes-selling business. She will buy clothes of different varieties of better quality with the loan amount. This will give her more chance to make better sales and increase her profits. 

Zahida is confident that her business will grow further after the loan investment.   

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Zahida.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 48 years old and married with 3 children.

Jocelyn works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional inventory to sell in her sari-sari store.

Jocelyn has borrowed and repaid 18 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 15 years and also earns an income from a restaurant.

Jocelyn aspires to save money to build a house for her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory to sell in her sari-sari store

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a bananas buying-and-selling business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to purchase more stock of bananas to sell in her business.

Judith has been in this business for 5 years. She also earns an income from raising pigs and buying and selling of coconut shells.

Judith has been able to sustain her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to purchase a delivery truck in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of bananas to sell

loans.name: Muniskhon's Group

texts.en:
Muniskhon is the leader of this group. She is 46 and married to a constructor, whose monthly salary is 8000 soms. She has raised two sons, both of whom are working in Russia. Each month they transfer 7000 soms to their parents. Muniskhon works as a nurse in the hospital, her monthly salary is 7000 soms. 

In order to earn additional money for the family budget she breeds cattle and sells milk. In this way she earns additional 5000 soms per month. Muniskhon saved some money, and she applied for the loan because she needs additional funds to purchase more cattle. In the future she wants to see her younger son get married.



--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy works hard to support her family. She is married and has a bakery business in the Philippines. Nancy has been in this business for 5 years now.

Nancy requested a 30,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to purchase additional equipment and ingredients for her business. In the future, Nancy would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional equipment and ingredients for her business

loans.name: Jesusa

texts.en:
Jesusa is a 55-year-old married woman. She has seven grown up children. She describes herself as patient, quiet, and responsible. 

She is a vegetable vendor in the community. She has been involved in this business for ten years. She describes her biggest business challenge to be loss of products due to the perishable nature of goods. She will use the P10,000 loan to add to her stock of potatoes, onions, tomatoes and cabbage. She hopes that within five years in the future, she will be able to educate her children to high levels of education.

loans.use: to buy potatoes, onions, tomatoes and cabbages to sell

loans.name: Ernesto

texts.en:
Ernesto is an industrious father who is now 61 years old and who raised his family in a village. He has two adult children who are already married and have their own family. Through his patience and hard work, he gave his children the best education they needed. He has been a farmer for almost 45 years now and usually earns a profits of P27,000 in every harvest season. 

He aims to continue managing their rice fields to satisfy their basic necessities and save for future emergencies. But due to inadequate capital, he is asking for a loan of P25,000 to buy seeds, fertilizers and pesticides needed in rice farming. He believes that through this loan, he will able to increase their yields and income as he works hard and makes the best of it.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers and pesticides for rice farming

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena is 42 years old and married with 3 children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Rowena is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to buy additional piglets, vitamins, and feeds for her business.

Rowena has been raising pigs for 10 years and also earns additional income from selling electronic reloads (prepaid cell phone credits), a sari-sari store, and food vending.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets, vitamins, and feeds for her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita is 59 years old and she is married with ten children. She lives and works in Naguilan, a semi-urban area in Isabela province, with one dependent.
 
Lolita has a grocery business selling dry food. She is requesting a loan to purchase different products like sugar, canned goods and snack foods to sell. Lolita has been involved in this business for ten years. The main hardship that Lolita faces in her business is not being able to meet the high demands for products.

With her business profit, Lolita hopes to make enough money to provide for her kids, to buy land of her own, and for her children to find a good job.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snack foods and sugar to sell in her store

loans.name: Ibrahem

texts.en:
Ibrahem is a 56-year-old man. He is married and has three sons. He lives in Ramallah city in Palestine. He is a construction worker with a decent salary. 

Ibrahem wants to complete finishing his house by purchasing doors, windows, tiles, etc., but the amount of money he has isn't enough to pay so he needs to take a loan in the amount of $1030 from FATEN. When Ibrahem takes the loan which is repaid on a monthly basis, he will pay to purchase the needed things to complete finishing his house. In this way he will help to improve his family life and live in better and healthy conditions. Ibrahem is photographed in the picture.

loans.use: To pay for completing the finishing on his house by purchasing doors, windows, tiles, etc,  in order to live with the family in better conditions.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta is married with 10 children. She is 59 years old and lives in the province of Isabela. For the past 10 years, she has been raising pigs to earn a living. She has requested a loan of 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to purchase more pigs.

Viloeta is well-known in their community as a responsible and very patient mother.

In the future, she hopes to increase her earnings from pig raising so that her total net income is 50,000 PHP.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pig.

loans.name: Albert

texts.ru:
Алберт родился в 1979 г. в городе Капане; окончил Капанскую среднюю школу. Алберт живет с родителями пенсионерами, сестрой, женой и 2-х летним сыном. Жена Алберта не работает, сестра помогает Алберту в бизнесе.
С 1995 г. Алберт занимается частным предпринимательством: продажей овощей и фруктов, а также продажей цветов. На Капанском городском рынке Алберт арендует ларек, в котором торгует овощами и фруктами, привезенными из близлежащих деревень. Цветы Алберт привозит из Еревана, а сестра продает их и, таким образом, помогает брату содержать семью.  
Алберт является клиентом Нор Оризон на протяжении долгих лет и он всегда выполнял свои обязательства по выплате кредита без опозданий. Сейчас ему необходим кредит на сумму 700,000 драм для покупки лент, цветной бумаги, пенопласта, цветочных горшков и декоративных корзин для своего цветочного бизнеса, а также партии винограда, персиков, баклажанов и т.д. для перепродажи.
texts.en: Albert was born in 1979 in the city of Kapan.  He graduated from the Kapan secondary school.  Albert lives with his retired parents, sister, wife and two-year-old son.  Albert's wife does not work, and sister helps him with the business.  Since 1995, Albert has been involved in private enterprise and has been selling vegetables and fruits and also flowers.  Albert leases a retail outlet at the Kapan city market, where he sells vegetables and fruits that he brings from nearby villages.  Albert brings in flowers from Yerevan, and his sister sells them, and, thus, helps her brother to support the family.  Albert has been a client of Nor Horizon for many years and always fulfilled his responsibilities of repaying loan on-time.   He now needs a loan in the sum of 700,000 dram for the purchase of ribbons, color paper, foam, flower pots and decorative baskets for his flower business, and also for the purchase of grapes, peaches, eggplants, etc. for resale.

loans.use: to buy ribbons, color paper, foam, flower pots and decorative baskets for his flower business, and also to buy grapes, peaches, eggplants, etc. for resale

loans.name: Iruzvan's Group

texts.en:
Iruzvan is the leader of this group. She is 49 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband she brings up a daughter and a son. The son works in construction in Russia and the daughter studies at school. In order to earn their livelihood the family breeds livestock and then resells it at the higher price after being fattened. In this way they earn from 5,000 to 7,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan Iruzvan wants to purchase two livestock animals for breeding, fattening and further reselling. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en:
This is Teodora, 54, a resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. She is a widow with one child. She manages her own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses and support her child’s schooling. 

Teodora maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalog, and these are the profits that dealers are counting on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 4,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php11,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy merchandise items and products needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as it expands.  

Teodora dreams of growing her business in the coming years, just as she fervently hopes that her child will be able to graduate one day and finish his studies. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for merchandise items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda is 48 years old, married, and has four children. Her spouse works as a local farmer. She believes that diligence is the mother of good fortune. Aside from raising hogs, she also has a variety store for additional income. She sells sugar, coffee, soap and shampoo to the people in the village where she lives. She has been operating the business for five years. Minimal profit of P2,000 monthly goes to school fees and daily meals. Sometimes, the profit isn't enough to cover all their expenses, especially for the increasing cost of commodities and school fees. 

She is asking for a loan of P20,000 to buy soft drinks, canned goods, instant noodles, soap, shampoo and toothpaste to sell in her store. With these additional grocery items, she will be able to increase her sales and generate more income.

In the future, Nilda would like to establish a larger store and make her family economically stable.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, canned goods, instant noodles, soap, shampoo and toothpaste to sell in her store.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a 27-year-old single woman living with her parents. She has seven years of experience working as a hairdresser. She started running her own business seven years ago. 

With her requested loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua, she will buy hairdressing and beauty products necessary to run her business. Her house is her working place, and this is suitable for most of her customers because they feel relaxed as if they are at home.

This is Fatima's first experience with Al Majmoua. She hopes to improve her standard of living. She expects to open a larger beauty salon in the future to meet all of her customers' needs and requests.

loans.use: to buy hairdressing and beauty products necessary for her business.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is 40 years old. She is married and has eight children. Rosemarie is the sole breadwinner, and her only income comes from raising pigs and selling them in the future at the local market. Every year, she buys young pigs from the farms near their village. She raises them with the help of her husband and children and then sells the pigs to local butchers. Her monthly profit is about P2,000. She would like to expand her business, as the income from her existing herd isn't enough to provide for her family. She wants to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

In the future, she hopes that her children finish their schooling.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins to fatten her pig.

loans.name: Sinfrosa

texts.en:
Sinfrosa is 72 years old, married and has two children. She has an agricultural business raising pigs in the Philippines. Sinfrosa has been raising pigs for 10 years now and has borrowed 19 times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

Sinfrosa requested a 19,500 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to purchase additional feed and vitamins for her pigs. In the future, Sinfrosa would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to purchase additional feed and vitamins for her pigs

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Verline

texts.en:
Verline is 38 years old and married with 3 children.

Verline works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more inventory to sell in her sari-sari store.

Verline has borrowed and repaid 2 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 1 year and also earns an income from raising livestock.

Verline aspires to save money to expand her business and to purchase a vehicle.

loans.use: To buy more inventory to sell in her sari-sari store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en:
This is Carlos, 55, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Jocelyn, a housewife, and is the father of their two children. The oldest is already working while the youngest is still in high school. By the grace of God, Carlos has managed to support his children's schooling. At this time, he is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Carlos oversees operations of their tricycle transportation business. They have one tricycle unit that carries up to five passengers to their destination within the community, all of whom are paying a boundary (daily quota) each day, Aside from this, his wife is also managing their small ornamental plants business. Their regular passengers and customers are from the local community. He earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a Php9,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan for the maintenance of his tricycle, and part of the loan will be used to buy fertilizers, plastic pots and wire for their ornamental plant business. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business.  

He dreams that all his children will finish their education and have a good future. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for the spare parts and maintenance of their tricycle unit.

loans.name: Allem

texts.en:
Allem is 43 years old and married.

Allem works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her sari-sari store.

Allem has borrowed and repaid 16 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 8 years and also earns an income from food vending and fruits and vegetables sales.

Allem aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy items to sell in her sari-sari store

loans.name: Halimahon's Group

texts.en:
Halimahon is the treasurer of this group. She is 53 and married to a constructor. Together with her husband she has raised a daughter and a son. The son works in Russia and the daughter is a schoolteacher. Halimahon has been working as a teacher of mathematics for twenty years. 

She also breeds cattle for making additional money. She breeds cattle and then resells it at the higher price after being fattened. In this way she earns an additional 4,000 soms per month. 

With money received from the loan she wants to purchase sheep for breeding, fattening and further reselling. In the future, with the profits gained from reselling livestock, Halimahon plans to finish their house construction.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep.

loans.name: Aniceta

texts.en:
Aniceta is married and has a tailoring business in the Philippines. She works hard to support her family.
